items.abstract: <jats:p>ABSTRACT In the revision of the Alismataceae from Brazil, the author recognizes 38 species of the genus Echinodorus and 7 of Sagittaria. Keys to the determination of these species as well as botanical descriptions and 48 illustrations are provided in this work.</jats:p>
title: Alismataceae of Brazil

items.abstract: <jats:p>Methods of estimation of the oriented direction distribution (i.e. the distribution of unit outer normals over the boundary) of a planar set from the convex ring are proposed. The methods are based on an estimation of the area dilation of the investigated set by chosen test sets.</jats:p>
title: Estimation of oriented direction distribution of a planar body

reference.volume-title: Das geometrische Kovariogramm und verwandte Größen zweiter Ordnung.

items.abstract:
<jats:p>Let <jats:italic>X, Y</jats:italic> be two sets of positive reach in ℝ<jats:italic>
                  <jats:sup>d</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic>. The translative integral formula says that, for 0 ≦ <jats:italic>k</jats:italic> ≦ <jats:italic>d</jats:italic> − 1 and bounded Borel subsets <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>B</jats:italic> ε ℝ<jats:italic>
                  <jats:sup>d</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic>,
<jats:disp-formula id="S0001867800048436_deqn1">
                  <jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" mimetype="image" position="float" xlink:href="S0001867800048436_eqn1" xlink:type="simple" />
               </jats:disp-formula>
where <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0001867800048436_inline1" xlink:type="simple" /> is the curvature measure (of order <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>) of <jats:italic>X</jats:italic> and <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0001867800048436_inline2" xlink:type="simple" /> is the mixed curvature measure of the sets <jats:italic>X, Y</jats:italic> and order <jats:italic>r, S</jats:italic> [1]. The mixed curvature measures are introduced by means of rectifiable currents, which leads to a relatively simple proof of (1). The proof needs an additional assumption on <jats:italic>X, Y</jats:italic> assuring that also reach (<jats:italic>X</jats:italic> ∩ <jats:italic>Y<jats:sub>z</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic>) &gt; 0 for almost all <jats:italic>z</jats:italic>. This assumption is satisfied automatically for convex bodies, in dimension 2, or for sets with a sufficiently smooth boundary. Using the additivity of mixed curvature measures, (1) can be extended to unions of sets of positive reach.</jats:p>
title: Mixed curvature measures and a translative integral formula
